lexUnit.name: peek.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a quick or furtive look

sentence.text: I chanced a peek at myself .
Before starting the walk we could n't resist a peek at the 12th century Norman Cathedral , the oldest in Wales .
It turned out that he 'd inched along the parapet -- a thin one about six inches wide -- and had a good peek at us through the windows .
We also take a peek at Keith in the kitchen of his Devon pub .
A peek in the waste containers at the end of the lunch break is a good indicator of what should n't appear on the menu in future .
I caught myself taking a quick peek in the mirror behind the bar to see if my tie was straight .
A peek into someone 's kettle will reveal either a clean element or one coated with a white , chalky substance , depending on the local water type .
Carson took a peek into the brown paper on the Tube .
I had a quick peek into the kitchen but it was empty .
The front of the machine sports some graceful curves , but it 's only when you take a peek round the back that you get some inkling that this one is different .

A peek through the window showed that the taxi had arrived , brief farewells were made to the men , and Karl left , promising to ring them the next day and making mock threats to Erika and Paul should they forget to meet him the following Sunday .
Should I just take a peek through the windows of those double doors -- see if I can see him -- Vern 's dad ?
` Take a peek under the cloche , my dear .
I took a quick peek inside : bed , drawers , small bathroom with shower .
She had a peek inside , and what do you think she found ? "
